content.description:
Start up the hand and finger crack through a slightly steep section.  Continue left up the diagonal crack to keep it 5.8, or go straight up through the small roof for a fun 5.9 offwidth finish.

20 feet left of Edible Panties.
Standard rack.

Hand crack on the left side of the wall. The start is a 5.9 boulder move just off the ground, then the rest is solid 5.7 with good jamming. Ends after moving right, out of the crack, towards the top.

Left of Octopus' Garden
Anchor is bolts with chains

A beautiful route with several cruxes and good gear. Be bold on this one, though, as one of the lower cruxes has groundfall potential and the upper one has big air potential.  
  
 This route is easily top roped by climbing any of the routes to the left and moving the rope to the anchors on top of this route.

The obvious thin crack system on the right hand side of the wall.
thin gear to #2 camalot

Starts by a horizontal slot - press up to clip first bolt. Keep climbing.

3 bolts + SR

Climb up the leaning hand, and finger crack. As the crack peters out difficult face climbing leads past 4 bolts. There are several cruxes featuring desperate crystal pinching, crimping in tiny solution pockets, and difficult high steps. The penultimate crux is stepping across to regain a final crack and easier slab move to the arete and the anchor.

Big thanks to everyone who gets stoked on our new climbs and continue to encourage us. Much gratitude those who have contributed some of their hard earned dollars to the Sea to Sky Route Development gofundme campaign. Funds go directly to high quality bolts and anchors used on routes such as this.

https://www.gofundme.com/seatoskyroutedevelopment 



Located a few meters right of Electric Balls.


A few cams up to .75, medium nuts, quickdraws. 4 bolts and a fixed lower off anchor.

Another great hand crack.

Climb up a block to gain a ledge which rises from right to left. At the left side of the ledge is a hand crack that goes up and slightly left. Follow this to the top. The crux may be getting in the crack itself.

Anchor at top. 


Left of the main wall.  There are other routes on this part of the cliff, but they were overgrown when I was there.
Gear to 2 inches (though there is one placement that could take a 3 inch piece if you've got it).

Sustained, thin and painful but so worth it.

This is the obvious slab directly between Edible Panties and Octopus Garden in the Shade
10 bolts with chain anchors

Like Unearthly Delights, this route has a spooky move that can be well protected. Not as sustained or difficult as its neighbor, but good fun nonetheless.

Start up the crack just left of Unearthly Delights, then step left across the slab to another crack system and follow that to the top and an anchor.
gear to 4"

Perfect hands. Start on the left side of an arrowhead-shaped flake (pointing up). Jam to the top. Toward the left side of the face. To the right of this route is a crack (Pipe Dream, 5.8) with a large tree in it, and the left is another crack (Edible Panties, 5.7) with a smaller tree in it. Standard Rack to 2 inches.

Fun hands, fists, and stacked hands. If you stay in the wide crack the whole way, the crux comes near the top. Otherwise you can hand traverse right at a horizontal crack into Monkey Quotient to an easier hand crack. The wide crack with the large tree in it, just to the right of Octopus Garden in the Shade. Rappel the route off two bolts. Big gear to #4 Camalot. Though there are lots of smaller placements to be had throughout.

A direct wide crack left of Unearthly Delights. This has some good OW practice. There are quite a few face holds and smaller cam placements so it's not all wide drudgery. But if you are not used to OW you will want a #4 for the lower wide part, and a #5 for the upper part. It is a good place to practice fist to hand stack or the butterfly hand stack. Middle of the wall, Pipe Dream is the route with tree in the crack that starts left of this. Monkey has same start as this, veers left. Unearthly is to the right. Mostly hand size cams and larger, but there are a few smaller cracks for nuts and smaller cams.
Bolted belay.

A really fun route that will be a little spooky for new 5.9 leaders, but is very well protected the entire way. Sustained and fun, probably the best route at the grade on the wall.

On the right hand side of the wall there are two obvious wide cracks. This route starts up the right crack and steps right into a crack at mid height, then right again at the top.
Gear to 3"

A wonderful moderate climbing area, mostly 5.8 and 5.9.  If you're coming up here to lead these (and they are nice), you might consider bringing a set of hexes and/or some larger cams (up to about #4 Camalot).  Many of the climbs can be led on a standard rack, but two or three are    w   i   d   e. 
  
 Because of the ease of top-roping (most climbs have rappel anchors), this place can be crowded on weekends.  Also a bit "buggy."
